Award.AwardTitle: Creative Robotics: an inclusive program for fostering diverse STEM talent in middle school

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This partnership brings together the Robotics Institute (Carnegie Mellon University), two institutions experienced in educational research and teacher development (Marshall University and West Liberty University) and school districts in West Virginia (Mingo County Schools) and Pennsylvania (Allegheny Valley School District). The key innovation of this project in the focal area of Identifying and Cultivating Exceptional Talent is its incorporation of robotics into courses for middle school students in a non-competitive setting to identify and cultivate talent in "exceptional computational thinking" and "exceptional engineering design." The project utilizes the Arts & Bots program which enables teachers to introduce craft-based robotics projects to students in disciplines as varied as art, science, health, or English.

The intellectual merit of this work is the analysis of the role of creative technology in student engineering engagement and the identification of unrecognized creative STEM talent. This contributes to STEM talent theories on computational thinking and engineering design and refines working definitions of technology fluency. The broader impacts include the integration of creativity with technology, refined professional development materials for teachers to support STEM talent, and models for school district-wide deployment of curricular innovation.

By executing the project with pre-service educational partners, a pathway to scaling is built so that the program may spread across a widening footprint of school districts. Research and evaluation focus on student engagement, knowledge, and attitudes as well as teachers' abilities to identify and support student talent.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Creative Robotics program has been a collaboration between a research university, schools, school districts, and schools of education dedicated to finding new ways for STEM talents to be encouraged, recognized, and diversified in all classrooms in middle school. This program has designed, deployed, and refined a creative robotics kit that enables non-technology teachers to integrate sculptural robotics into an expressive practice in the classroom: anatomical demonstrations in Physical Education; metaphorical allusions in Poetry; moving models of historical structures in in Social Studies; technology as an expressive medium in Art class. In each case, Creative Robotics has helped elucidate transdisciplinary integration, ensuring that STEM talents such as mechanical engineering and computer programming are not siloed, but rather embraced as expressive tools with authentic value in any disciplinary discourse. Our outcomes include the building blocks of such a curricular endeavour, from customized circuit boards and build kits to firmware and computer software for iconic programming and choreography. These kits are now in use in thousands of classrooms throughout the United States, including our close partners in Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Utah, and Georgia. In addition to creating and disseminating these Creative Robotics kits now nationally, this project has also studied the scientific questions pertaining to empowerment, agency, and learning surrounding this work. How will teachers be empowered to use such tools given their strict temporal deadlines? What learning outcomes can be demonstrated by students of such an unconventional program that breaks down barriers in education? We have published five papers identifying teacher engagement patterns, lasting teacher activity changes, technical student knowledge gains, design guidelines stemming from our curricular and interface work, and overall attitudinal shifts in both teachers and students. We believe the Creative Robotics program has demonstrated student learning and engagement strongly enough that this program can help to diversify future technologically fluent generations, helping decision-makers and societal discourse in our rapidly accelerating society to be more grounded by the reality of how technology can be a tool for empowerment and self-expression.
